text: between societies has decreased. Once poor countries like China have caught up considerably to the affluent West. Meanwhile within the West inequalities have widened. So we're thinking about the history of economic development in terms that are sort of sensitive to the big global vectors. That's one major narrative strand that I want to emphasize. And the last is globalization. A globalization is distinct from development insofar as it is the history of integration. Thinking about the history of development does not necessarily require us to be particularly attentive to the relationships among the world's economies. Thinking about the history of globalization does. At the beginning of the post-war era in 1945 the world's major economic units, which are the world's major nation states, are relatively self-contained, relatively autonomous, certainly by comparison with their relations today. So understanding how the global economy becomes more integrated and reflecting upon the sort of political and international consequences of that integration, which is to say globalization, will be a central priority for this course. What are you going to learn through all of this? Besides gaining an overview of recent world history, which I presume is the reason that most of you are here, I hope that you're going to learn to be adept consumers of history. I'm not going to teach you everything you need to know about the recent past and nor is anybody else. If you can come away from this class with a sense of the landscape and with the skills necessary to drill down into particular historical details, into particular historical narratives, as your needs in the future require you to do, then I will have done my job. This is a course that doesn't, you know, aspire to teach you everything about history, that that would be impossible even if we had two semesters. Rather, what I want to do is to give you a sense of the historical landscape and to equip you with the skills and the tools that will enable you, as you require and see fit, to probe more deeply into events in your own time and on your own terms. How are we going to do this? Well, at this point a walk through the syllabus might help. Does anybody not have a copy of the syllabus, by the way? Okay, where are the remaining syllabi? Is there a pile of them somewhere? Okay, maybe we could send one to the back. The syllabus is available on the B-Space website, by the way, so if you don't have a copy in front of you then you can easily acquire one. The syllabus will just give you a basic overview of the narrative progression of this lecture course. We're going to start off, you know, the substance on Thursday talking about the world crisis of the 1930s and 1940s. How did the Second World War and its resolution foreground the history of the post-war world? Next we'll talk about the Cold War in the second week, or the creation of new nation states in the global south, and the consolidation of welfare states in the global north. Week four will make comparisons between the political economy of the socialist world and the managed capitalism of the West in the 1950s and 1960s.
